Fig 6 Heterogeneous metal trimer catalysts on Mo2TiC2O2 MXene for highly active N2 conversion to NH3 Pengfei Shu Investigation Writing – original draft a Xiaosi Qi Supervision Writing – review & editing a Qiong Peng Methodology Supervision Conceptualization Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Yanli Chen Conceptualization a Xiu Gong Investigation Validation a Yue Zhang Supervision b Fangping Ouyang Investigation Validation b Zhimei Sun Writing – review & editing c ⁎ a College of Physics, Guizhou University, Guiyang 550025, China College of Physics Guizhou University Guiyang 550025 China aCollege of Physics, Guizhou University, Guiyang 550025, China b School of Physics and Electronics, Central South University, Changsha 410083, China School of Physics and Electronics Central South University Changsha 410083 China bSchool of Physics and Electronics, Central South University, Changsha 410083, China c School of Materials Science and Engineering, Beihang University, Beijing 100191, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Beihang University Beijing 100191 China cSchool of Materials Science and Engineering, Beihang University, Beijing 100191, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Activating the inert basal plane of functional-group-terminated MXenes is highly desirable for non-noble metal MXenes applied for the N2 reduction reaction (NRR) to value-added ammonia (NH3), but remains a significant challenge. Herein, we report the coupled interactions and catalytic mechanism of the supported trimeric metal M3 single-cluster catalysts (SCCs) on oxygen-vacancy-rich Mo2TiC2O2 (VO−Mo2TiC2O2) MXene materials for catalyzing this difficult reaction via spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Energy and electronic property analysis showed that the robust structural stability of the M3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 catalysts stemmed from the vacancy defects, electronegativity difference, and significant charge redistribution. Based on the unique bidirectional electron transfer activation mechanism, the N2 adsorption strength can be well represented by a simple descriptor of the valence electrons in the d orbitals of M3 trimers. Remarkably, these confined Rh3, Ru3, Ni3 and Co3 SCCs on VO−Mo2TiC2O2 were capable of providing superior electrocatalytic activity and selectivity toward the NRR with ultra-low limiting potentials of −0.23, −0.32, −0.42 and −0.44 V, respectively. Finally, a mechanistic investigation illustrated that the valence electrons, charge transfer, and d-band center of the M3 active sites could collectively act as good descriptors to correlate the structure and NRR activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Anchoring trimeric Rh3, Ru3, Ni3 and Co3 clusters endows Mo2TiC2O2 MXene with superior electrocatalytic reactivity and selectivity toward N2 reduction to NH3. Keywords Heterogeneous single-cluster catalyst Mo2TiC2O2 MXene Electrocatalytic N2-to-NH3 conversion Valence electron descriptor Two-step strategy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction NH3 is an extremely important chemical raw material in agricultural planting and industrial production, and it is also a promising clean energy carrier [1]. In the context of the global energy crisis and increasingly serious environmental problems, the electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction (NRR) powered by renewable energy offers a more eco-friendly and efficient route than the Haber–Bosch process for N2-to-NH3 conversion, which provides a great benefit to the carbon-neutral energy cycle as well [2,3]. Nevertheless, there are still three key challenges that place severe limitations on NH3 synthesis: 1) N2 activation, 2) NRR selectivity vs. the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and 3) linear scaling limitations of the adsorption strengths between different N-involving intermediates [4–8]. Therefore, mining highly active and stable electrocatalysts is very desirable for the NRR, but remains a great challenge. Recently, heterogeneous single-atom catalysts (SACs) have aroused significant attention because of their extremely high metal utilization and unique catalytic performances [9–13]. However, the large-scale preparation of SACs is still quite difficult [14,15]. Alternatively, single-cluster catalysts (SCCs), where metal clusters are uniformly immobilized on a heterogeneous substrate with a large specific surface [16], have rapidly been developed as an extended family member. Benefiting from the synergetic effects, SCCs generally present special advantages over SACs in terms of the selective modulation of the adsorption strength of the key reaction species to break the scaling relations in NH3 synthesis, further lowering the energy input. For example, Ji et al. experimentally found that Ru3/CN SCCs showed better catalytic performances (100% conversion, 100% chemoselectivity, and turnover frequency as high as 4320 h–1) toward the oxidation of 2-aminobenzyl alcohol than Ru1/CN SACs [17]. On the basis of Cu n (n = 1–5) cluster-doped monolayer Mo2CO2 MXene defects, the Cu3 trimer exhibits the highest stability and a superior catalytic ability for CO oxidation [18]. It is well known that MXenes, as newly emerging two-dimensional transition metal carbides and nitrides, can act not only as catalysts but also as catalyst substrates [19–25]. The general formula is M n +1X n T x , where M represents a transition metal, X represents C or N, n varies from 1 to 4, and T x denotes surface terminations [26]. Benefiting from their abundant surface functional groups, good hydrophilicity, and excellent metallic conductivities, non-noble-metal MXenes have attracted great attentions in the catalysis field [27]. Recently, Mo2CTx, Mo2TiC2Tx and Mo2Ti2C3Tx (T = O and/or OH groups) have been synthesized in acidic solutions [28], where Mo2TiC2Tx displays the highest conductivity, making it more promising for electron transformation in the electrocatalytic process. Notably, the surface OH groups can be converted into O termination via high temperature annealing or metal adsorption [29]. Nevertheless, for O-terminated MXene materials, their NRR active sites are limited to the exposed edge sites [23]. It is still a challenge to endow the basal plane with a high catalytic activity for NRR [24]. To mimic biological nitrogenase, constructing metal trimer SCCs on defective Mo2TiC2O2 MXene substrate may be a fascinating strategy to solve the aforementioned challenge. Among the common NRR catalysts, the active components involve Ti, V, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zr, Nb, Mo, Ru, and Rh atoms [30–34]. However, the coupled interactions between the cluster active sites and MXene, as well as the molecular mechanism of the N2-to-NH3 reaction, are far from understood. Therefore, in this study, we focused on oxygen-vacancy-rich Mo2TiC2O2 MXene-supported trimeric metal M3 SCCs to investigate their catalytic characteristics, including their structural stability, catalytic activity, and selectivity as well as the atomic and molecular mechanisms, via a universal two-step strategy combined with density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Based on the bidirectional activation mechanism of N2 adsorption, a simple valence electron descriptor was proposed to provide key insights into the relationship between the intrinsic properties of M3 active centers and the NRR activity. In particular, Rh3, Ru3, Ni3 and Co3 SCCs were predicted to possess superior stability, NRR reactivity and selectivity, outperforming the stepped Ru(0001) catalyst and consequently promising to break the bottleneck of N2-to-NH3 production. 2 Model and computational method All the spin-polarized DFT calculations were implemented in the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [35]. The exchange-correlation energy was described using the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional in the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [36]. To deal with the weak interactions between the catalyst and reaction intermediates, the DFT-D3 semiempirical scheme [37] was used in all the calculations. The cutoff energy of the plane-wave basis was set to 500 eV. In the structural optimization, the Brillouin zone was sampled by a 3 × 3 × 1 k-point grid using the Monkhorst–Pack scheme, while a denser k-point grid with dimensions of 4 × 4 × 1 was employed for the electronic property computations. It was reported that the solvation effect only changes the stability of N-containing intermediates by about 0.1 eV [38]. Considering the large number of calculations and limited impact on the results [39], the solvation effect was not considered in this work. Pristine Mo2TiC2O2 MXene has a 2D hexagonal crystal structure. It consists of seven atomic layers stacked in the sequence of O-Mo-C-Ti-C-Mo-O. The calculated lattice constant (a) was 2.93 Å, and the layer thickness (h) was 7.61 Å, agreeing well with the reported results (a = 2.94 Å, h = 7.59 Å) of Si et al. [40]. A 3 × 3 × 1 Mo2TiC2O2 supercell with a vacuum layer over 20 Å in the z-direction was constructed as the plane to anchor the metal clusters. On the Mo2TiC2O2 MXene surface, different numbers of oxygen vacancy (VO) defects were examined by calculating the vacancy formation energy ( E f v ): (1) E f v = E ( V O ) + n 2 E ( O 2 ) − E ( MXene ) , where E ( V O ) , E ( O 2 ) , and E ( M X e n e ) refer to the total energies of the oxygen-vacancy-rich surface, the gas phase oxygen molecules, and the pristine MXene surface, respectively, and n represents the number of oxygen vacancies. The lower the formation energy, the easier it was for an oxygen vacancy to form. Furthermore, the formation energy (ΔE f) of the M n /MXene SCCs was calculated to assess the stability [18,41]: (2) Δ E f = ( E M n / MXene − E MXene − n E TM ) / n , where E M n / M X e n e represents the total energy of the M n /MXene SCCs, E M X e n e is the energy of the MXene substrate with oxygen vacancy defects, and E T M is the energy per atom in the bulk metal. The formation energy included both the cohesive energy of the gas phase M n cluster and its binding energy on the surface. Therefore, we could directly evaluate the stability of the M n cluster by Δ E f . A lower value of Δ E f suggested a better thermodynamical stability. For the electrocatalytic N2-to-NH3 reaction, the adsorption energy ( Δ E N 2 ads . ) of N2 molecules on the catalyst surface was calculated as (3) Δ E N 2 ads . = E * N 2 − E N 2 − E * , where E * N 2 , E N 2 , and E * denote the total energies of the catalyst with adsorbate, the free adsorbate, and the bare catalyst, respectively. As for N2 reduction to NH3 in an acidic electrolyte, H+ serves as the proton donor, so the overall reaction scheme of NRR can be written as (4) N 2 + 6 H + + 6 e − ⇆ 2 NH 3 . Depending on the adsorption configurations of N2, the NRR can involve four different mechanisms [42,43]. If N2 is adsorbed via an end-on configuration, the NRR will proceed through distal and alternating mechanisms. However, if N2 is adsorbed via a side-on configuration, the NRR will proceed through enzymatic and consecutive mechanisms [44]. Regardless of the reaction mechanism, the whole NRR involves six electron transfer steps. Based on the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model [45,46], the Gibbs free energy change ΔG for each elementary step was determined by the difference between the free energy of the initial state and the final state: (5) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E ZPE − T Δ S + Δ G U + Δ G pH , where ΔE is the adsorption energy of N-containing intermediates due to the reaction, obtained from DFT calculations, ΔE ZPE is the change in the zero-point energy, T is the temperature (T = 298.15 K), ΔS is the entropy change, ΔG U = –neU is the free energy contribution related to the electrode potential U, and ΔG pH is the correction of the H+ free energy by the concentration. ΔG pH = 2.303 × k B T × pH, where k B is the Boltzmann constant. Herein, the free energy at 0 V and a pH of 0 was computed. More calculation details are provided in the Supporting Information (SI). The thermodynamic values of N2, H2, and NH3 molecules and the reaction intermediates are summarized in Tables S1 and S2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural stability Catalyst stability plays a dominant role in N2-to-NH3 conversion. In experiments, Mo2TiC2Tx produced a large reduction in the =O concentration after annealing at 700 and 775 °C [47]. This means that inherent vacancy defects are inevitably generated on a synthetic MXene surface [48,49]. As shown in Fig. S1a, to model the defective Mo2TiC2O2 MXene, a surface oxygen atom was removed to create a vacancy defect. It was found that on the monolayer Mo2TiC2O2 surface, a single oxygen vacancy (VO) was more easily formed than two or three vacancies. The corresponding vacancy formation energy was only half that of MoS2 (3.65 vs. 6.27 eV) [50]. In addition, compared with the pristine VO-free Mo2TiC2O2, the defective surface could more effectively stabilize the trimeric metal M3 SCCs. For example, Fe3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 in Fig. S1b had less positive formation energy (0.11 eV) than Fe3/Mo2TiC2O2 (0.53 eV), demonstrating its better stability. As reported by Cheng et al., the VO defect was favorable for stabilizing metal clusters on the MXene substrate [18]. Based on the defective VO−Mo2TiC2O2 substrate with a single oxygen vacancy, a series of possible M n (n = 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5) cluster models were further examined, as shown in Fig. 1 a. Here, M represents the common components of recently reported NRR catalysts, involving Ti, V, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zr, Nb, Mo, Ru, and Rh [31]. To guess the structure, also taking Fe n /VO−Mo2TiC2O2 as an example, we started from a single Fe atom supported on a VO−Mo2TiC2O2 substrate and then added the second, third, fourth, and fifth Fe atoms. Based on the structural symmetry of VO−Mo2TiC2O2, distinct binding configurations for a specific Fe n cluster were tested, as shown in Fig. S2. Based on the comparison of the energy values, the Fe3 trimer was identified as the most stable single-cluster mode on the VO−Mo2TiC2O2 surface, where each Fe atom was coordinated with two O atoms owing to the electronegativity difference. Experimentally, atomically dispersed Ru3 clusters on metal–organic frameworks have been synthesized based on a cage-separated precursor preselection and pyrolysis strategy [17]. Therefore, herein, we will focus on the immobilized M3 SCCs on the VO−Mo2TiC2O2 MXene substrate and explore their stability, NRR potentials, and underlying catalytic mechanism. Given the most stable configuration of M3 clusters, Fig. 1b summarizes the formation energy (ΔE f) for all the considered M3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 systems. Compared with experimentally available Pd3/ND@G (ΔE f = 0.62 eV) and Cu3/ND@G (ΔE f = 0.95 eV in Fig. S3) as well as the theoretically predicted Fe3/θ-Al2O3 (ΔE f = 1.25 eV) SCCs [51–53], the ΔE f values of M3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2, ranging from −1.04 to 1.39 eV, were comparable or even more negative. Based on the formation energy of 1.25 eV for Fe3 single cluster catalyst reported by Liu et al. [53], we took no more than 20% of 1.25 eV (i.e., 1.5 eV) as a criterion to assess the stability of the catalyst. These results illustrate the good stability and synthesis accessibility of M3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 SCCs under certain conditions. Next, the charge density difference and charge transfer were further analyzed, as shown in Fig. 2 , to reveal the coupling mechanism between the trimer M3 cluster and the VO−Mo2TiC2O2 substrate. There were a large number of electrons transferred from the M3 cluster to the MXene surface (Fig. 2a). For example, Fe3 lost about 1.54 electrons, which were transferred to the VO−Mo2TiC2O2 surface. More charge transfer corresponds to a higher bonding strength of M3 clusters on the substrate (Fig. 2b). Therefore, it can be concluded that the stability of the M3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 catalysts was attributed to vacancy defects, electronegativity differences, and significant charge redistribution. 3.2 Bidirectional activation mechanism and valence electron descriptor for N2 adsorption For N2 reduction to NH3, N2 chemisorption is the fundamental prerequisite [54]. Different from the pristine Mo2TiC2O2 basal plane, which exhibited inferior adsorption for N2 molecules, the positively charged M3 clusters could accommodate the lone pair electrons of N2, serving as active sites to adsorb and activate the N2 reactant. Because the initial adsorption manner of N2 had a significant influence on the subsequent reduction mechanism, the side-on and end-on configurations were tested, as shown in Fig. S4. The associative side-on mode with more negative adsorption energy was identified as the optimal configuration. In this configuration, the N–N bond length was elongated from the initial 1.11 Å in the gas phase to 1.19–1.40 Å on the considered M3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 SCCs (Table S3), demonstrating the sufficient activation of N2. Such a stretched N–N bond length was comparable to that of N2 (1.26 Å) on the Fe3/θ-Al2O3 surface [53], where the adsorbed *N2 was difficult to dissociate at room temperature with a relatively high dissociation barrier (1.89 eV), but it easily hydrogenated to *N2H instead. To illuminate the activation mechanism of N2 adsorption, the electronic properties were investigated. The widely accepted N2 activation mechanism is electrons being transferred from the d orbitals of the metal atoms to the antibonding orbitals of N2, but the reverse transfer of electrons from N2 lone-pair electrons to the unoccupied metal d orbitals is negligible [2]. By analyzing the molecular orbitals in Fig. 3 a and the projected density of states (PDOS) in Fig. 3b for N2 adsorption on Fe3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2, it was found that trimetric Fe3 atoms provided partially unoccupied d orbitals to receive lone pair electrons in N2-σ bonding orbitals, while the occupied d electrons could also enter the π* antibonding orbitals of N2. As displayed in Fig. 3b, there was a strong hybridization between the half-filled Fe-d orbitals and the antibonding orbitals of N2-π*, resulting in N2-π* orbitals being widened. The N2-π* orbitals were half-filled by electrons from the Fe3 minority β-spin d orbitals, forming partially occupied d-π* orbitals. In addition, slight hybridization was found between the half-filled Fe-d orbitals and the bonding orbitals of N2-σ, yielding a bonding peak in the projected crystal orbital Hamilton population (pCOHP). This indicated that electrons were transferred from N2-σ orbitals to Fe-d orbitals. The synergistic effect between the electrons lost in the bonding orbitals and electrons gained in the antibonding orbitals induced a reduction of the N2 bond order to 3−(a + b)/2, effectively weakening the NN triple bond. This “push–pull” force made it easier for trimer M3 active sites to bind with N2 and other reaction intermediates through a unique bidirectional activation mechanism. Based on the bidirectional activation mechanism, a simple descriptor only involving the valence electron in the metal's d orbitals is proposed to correlate the N2 adsorption strength. As shown in Fig. 3c, the N2 adsorption energy ( Δ E N 2 ads . ) had a linear relationship when plotted against the number of valence electrons in the d orbital of trimer M3 clusters ( θ d ). The following linear relationship was found by fitting the data set, where the coefficient of determination (R2) was 0.92: (6) Δ E N 2 ads . = 0.57 × θ d − 5.04 ( R 2 = 0.92 ) . This indicated that the N2 adsorption strength could be well characterized by a simple descriptor θ d . A lower value of θ d means that the M3 SCCs possessed a stronger N2 adsorption capacity. According to the Sabatier principle [55], an ideal catalyst binds reaction intermediates with optimal binding strengths that are neither too strong nor too weak. Owing to the bidirectional activation mechanism, we can better elucidate the moderate N2 adsorption strength on the Fe3, Co3, Ni3, Mo3, Ru3, and Rh3 SCCs with partially occupied d orbitals. 3.3 Two-step strategy to screen efficient NRR catalysts An efficient NRR catalyst requires a balance of stability, catalytic activity, and selectivity for the HER. Next, by systematically analyzing the relative stability of N-containing intermediates and the reaction mechanisms in Fig. 4 a, a two-step strategy with high generalizability was adopted to rapidly evaluate the catalytic activity of stable M3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 applied for the NRR. In the first step, an N2 adsorption energy below −0.50 eV ( Δ E N 2 ads . < − 0.50 eV) and an *N2 protonation reaction free energy below 0.55 eV ( Δ G * N 2 → * N 2 H < 0.55 eV) were used to filter out low reactive species. In the second step, the reaction free energy of *NH2 protonation below 0.55 eV ( Δ G * NH 2 → * NH 3 < 0.55 eV) and the desorption energy of *NH3 below 0.70 eV ( Δ G * NH 3 des . < 0.70 eV) were used to further single out efficient NRR catalysts that satisfied the first step criteria. Notably, for N2 associative adsorption, these four elementary steps exist in all reaction mechanisms [56]. The abovementioned screening criteria were based on the following four theoretical bases. First, the chemisorption and activation of inert N2 molecules are the prerequisite during the NRR [54], so the N2 adsorption energy Δ E N 2 ads . should be more negative than −0.50 eV, corresponding to spontaneous chemisorption ( Δ G N 2 < 0 ). In addition, at the first protonation step, hydrogenation of *N2 into *N2H, requires weakening the strong NN bond and inevitably consumes a large amount of energy, resulting in a relatively positive reaction free energy [57,58]. Furthermore, at the sixth protonation step (*NH2 → *NH3), *NH2 is prone to be stabilized on the catalyst surface, leading to an uphill reaction free energy. To ensure the maximum free energy change ΔG max of the predicted catalysts close to or smaller than that of the Ru(0001) stepped surface, which exhibits the best NRR reactivity among bulk metals [38], Δ G * N 2 → * N 2 H and Δ G * NH 2 → * NH 3 should not exceed 0.55 eV. This can be well verified by previous theoretical work, where the hydrogenation reactions of *N2 and *NH2 were usually found to be the potential limiting steps of the whole NRR process [59–62]. Finally, rapid removal of the synthesized *NH3 is also critical [63], so the *NH3 desorption energy should be smaller than 0.70 eV. Fig. 4b and 4c show the two-step screening results for N2 capture and hydrogenation and for NH3 production and desorption, respectively. Only four candidates met both criteria and were finally screened out as potential NRR catalysts, i.e., Co3, Ni3, Ru3, and Rh3 SCCs supported on VO−Mo2TiC2O2. Such a two-step strategy was further justified by comparison with previously reported NRR catalysts, such as Ti2-Pc, V2-Pc, Ti3C2OH, and Mo/Ti2NO2 [23,32,64]. 3.4 Catalytic activity and selectivity For the screened Co3, Ni3, Ru3, and Rh3 candidates, to confirm whether they truly exhibited high catalytic activity, the entire NRR processes were systematically investigated. Starting from N2 side-on adsorption, enzymatic and consecutive mechanisms were taken into consideration. Figs. 5 and S5 show the free energy diagrams and the maximum free energy change ΔG max for each reaction pathway, where a smaller ΔG max indicates a better NRR reactivity on the catalyst surface. It is seen that for the NRR on Ru3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 SCCs, the energy-optimal pathway was a consecutive mechanism with a lower ΔG max of 0.32 eV (Fig. 5a). The corresponding potential limiting step was the protonation of *NH2 to *NH3. Similar results were also found for the Rh3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 SCCs with ΔG max of 0.23 eV (Fig. S5a). By contrast, for Co3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 and Ni3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 (Figs. S5b and S5c), the NRR process tended to proceed via an enzymatic mechanism, analogous to that of biological nitrogenases. Their potential limiting steps were the sixth protonation step (*NH2 → *NH3, ΔG max = 0.44 eV) and the fifth protonation step (*NH → *NH2, ΔG max = 0.42 eV). Importantly, the Co3, Ni3, Ru3, and Rh3 SCCs showed much lower ΔG max values than that of the stepped Ru(0001) benchmark (ΔG max = 0.98 eV) [38], demonstrating their better catalytic activities toward the NRR. Furthermore, considering that different atoms’ coordination plays a key role in the electronic structures and NRR reactivity [65], Fe2Ru and FeRu2 were taken as examples to explore the synergistic effect of heterotrinuclear catalysts. As displayed in Fig. S6a, for the NRR on the Fe3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 SCCs, the energy-optimal pathway was a consecutive mechanism with ΔG max of 0.52 eV. When a Ru atom was introduced to form Fe2Ru SCCs, ΔG max was reduced by 15% to 0.44 eV (Fig. 5b), where the energy-optimal pathway changed to enzymatic mechanism. As for the FeRu2 SCCs in Fig. S6b, ΔG max was further reduced to 0.41 eV via consecutive mechanism. Although the energetically optimal pathway varies with different Fe-Ru coordination in Fe2Ru and FeRu2 SCCs, the potential-limiting steps are the second proton step in the consecutive mechanism and the third proton step in the enzymatic mechanism. Overall, in comparison with Fe3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2, the synergy of Fe and Ru heteroatoms is beneficial for lowering the limiting potential. This can be attributed to the weaker Ru–N bonding than Fe–N bonding, resulting in the optimal interaction with N-involving intermediates when Fe and Ru sites coexisted. In Fig. 5c, a so-called volcano map was constructed to provide key insights into the relationship between the limiting potential and adsorption free energy of the key *N intermediate. The limiting potential (U L) was a good indicator to characterize the NRR activities of the different catalysts, where a smaller U L value indicated a better catalytic activity. The U L value was determined by (7) U L = − Δ G max / e , where ΔG max denotes the most positive Gibbs free-energy change of all the elementary steps [66]. Notably, with values appearing near the top of the volcano plot, the VO−Mo2TiC2O2-supported Rh3, Ru3, Co3, Ni3, Fe2Ru, and FeRu2 clusters were more active electrocatalysts toward the NRR. Their limiting potentials were −0.23, −0.32, −0.44, −0.42, −0.44, and −0.41 V, respectively, which were comparable to five reported NRR catalysts, i.e., Ti3C2OH (−0.4 V) [23], V2-Pc (−0.39 V), Ti2-Pc (−0.75 V) [32], 1T-Mo2C (−0.52 V) [67], and Mo/Ti2NO2 (−0.32 V) [64], even closer to the optimal value (0 V). This implied that they had superior catalytic activities for N2-to-NH3 conversion. In addition to the structural stability and reactivity, the catalytic selectivity of the target catalysts was further investigated. The HER has an equilibrium potential close to that of NRR, making it a major competing reaction and resulting in a poor N2-to-NH3 Faradaic efficiency. In this context, we compared the limiting potentials for the NRR and HER on the catalysts to estimate the catalytic selectivity (Fig. 5d). Theoretically, a catalyst delivering a more positive U L(NRR) value (closer to 0) suggests a significant preference for N2 reduction to NH3. For example, for the NRR on the Co3 catalyst, its U L(NRR) reached −0.44 V, which was much closer to zero than that of the HER (−0.80 V), suggesting its good catalytic selectivity for the NRR. Based on this selectivity criterion, it is worth noting that only four candidates, the Rh3, Ru3, Ni3 and Co3 SCCs, were finally screened out. Therefore, the combination of the stability, experimental feasibility, and catalytic activity analyses as well as the selectivity vs. HER results demonstrate the great potential of the Rh3, Ru3, and non-noble Ni3, Co3 SCCs on VO−Mo2TiC2O2 as highly active NRR catalysts. 3.5 Mechanistic investigations One significant issue is to understand the physical mechanism underlying the correlation between the M3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 catalyst structure and the NRR performance. To this end, electronic property calculations (including charge transfer, d-band center, integrated crystal orbital Hamilton population (ICOHP), valence-electron number and electronegativity) and energy analysis were used to provide insightful answers to this question. Fig. 6 a shows the variations of the N2 adsorption energy and activated N–N bond length as a function of charge transfer to N2 (see Supplementary Table S3 for specific data). Clearly, there is a good linear relationship between them, where R2 can reach 0.90 and 0.89, respectively. The more charge the N2 adsorbate gained from the M3 cluster active centers, the stronger the N2 adsorption and the longer the N–N bond length. To gain a deeper understanding of the N2 adsorption characteristics on the cluster surfaces, we examined the intrinsic correlation between the charge transfer to N2 and the ICOHP in Fig. 6b and Supplementary Fig. S7. Interestingly, it was found that a more negative value of the ICOHP corresponds to more bonding states and stronger N2 adsorption. Furthermore, as discussed above, the N2 adsorption strength was significantly affected by the valence electrons in the d orbital of the M3 cluster atoms. Therefore, the d-band center (εd) of M3 cluster atoms in the catalytic center was also calculated to deeply investigate the potential relationship between N2 activation and the NRR performance (see Fig. 6c). The d-band center is the average of the spin-up and spin-down channels of trimer M3 clusters. The N2 adsorption energy exhibited a good linear scaling relation with the d-band center (R2 = 0.94). Notably, the NRR limiting potential vs. d-band center delivered a universal volcano relationship, attributed to the Sabatier principle. The aforementioned results imply that for the M3 SCCs supported on the VO-Mo2TiC2O2 MXene substrate, the charge transfer, ICOHP value, valence electrons in the d orbital, and d-band center can collectively serve as descriptors to characterize their N2 activation and NRR performances. Despite great efforts in both academia and industry to develop high-quality catalyst materials, further reducing the NRR limiting potentials for ammonia synthesis, the great challenge is determining the linear scaling relations between the adsorption energies of key intermediates [68]. An alternative strategy is to circumvent the scaling relations, that is, to find ways to stabilize the adsorbed state of one of the reaction intermediates while destabilizing others. This requires multifunctional active centers on the catalyst surface to bind reaction intermediates in different ways. As displayed in Fig. S8, for *N2, *N2H, *N, *NH2, and *NH3 intermediates adsorbed on the M3 SCCs, their energetically favorable adsorption sites are distinct. Specifically, *N preferred to adsorb at the center of the M3 triangular structure, while *NH3 tended to adsorb at the edges. This demonstrated that loading trimer M3 SCCs on the VO-Mo2TiC2O2 substrate provided multifunctional active sites for N-containing intermediate adsorption, which may be a promising strategy to circumvent the scaling relation limitations in ammonia synthesis. To confirm this conclusion, we further examined the relations between the adsorption-free energies of several key N-containing intermediates, such as *N2H, *N, and *NH3. The plots of Δ G * N 2 H versus Δ G * N exhibited a linear scaling relation, as shown in Fig. 6d. However, the widespread data points in Δ G * N H 3 were observed at the same value of Δ G * N . This spread suggested that Δ G * N did not correlate well with Δ G * N H 3 . In other words, for M3 SCCs on Mo2TiC2O2 MXene defects, the adsorption strengths of *N and *NH3 could be selectively modulated, breaking the scaling relations between the reaction intermediates to achieve a higher catalytic activity for the NRR. 4 Conclusion In summary, the electrocatalytic specialty and activity mechanism of M3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 SCCs for N2-to-NH3 conversion were explored based on spin-polarized DFT calculations. The unsaturated oxygen vacancies and significant electron redistribution boosted the structural stability of the M3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 catalysts. The associative adsorption and activation of N2 molecules were attributed to the bidirectional electron transfer between the σ orbitals, π* orbitals of N2, and d orbitals of M3 metal trimers. With the help of a general two-step screening strategy, the Rh3, Ru3, Ni3 and Co3 SCCs on VO−Mo2TiC2O2 were singled out as superior electrocatalysts toward the NRR. They present ultra-low limiting potentials of −0.23, −0.32, −0.42 and −0.44 V, and high NRR catalytic selectivity, outperforming most of the available experimental and theoretical references. These results greatly deepen the fundamental understanding of the catalytic mechanism and structure–activity relationship of trimetallic M3 active sites on VO−Mo2TiC2O2, and they will inspire more experimental and theoretical efforts to rationally design MXene-based NRR electrocatalysts for N2-to-NH3 conversion. coredata.dc:description: Activating the inert basal plane of functional-group-terminated MXenes is highly desirable for non-noble metal MXenes applied for the N2 reduction reaction (NRR) to value-added ammonia (NH3), but remains a significant challenge. Herein, we report the coupled interactions and catalytic mechanism of the supported trimeric metal M3 single-cluster catalysts (SCCs) on oxygen-vacancy-rich Mo2TiC2O2 (VO−Mo2TiC2O2) MXene materials for catalyzing this difficult reaction via spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Energy and electronic property analysis showed that the robust structural stability of the M3/VO−Mo2TiC2O2 catalysts stemmed from the vacancy defects, electronegativity difference, and significant charge redistribution. Based on the unique bidirectional electron transfer activation mechanism, the N2 adsorption strength can be well represented by a simple descriptor of the valence electrons in the d orbitals of M3 trimers. Remarkably, these confined Rh3, Ru3, Ni3 and Co3 SCCs on VO−Mo2TiC2O2 were capable of providing superior electrocatalytic activity and selectivity toward the NRR with ultra-low limiting potentials of −0.23, −0.32, −0.42 and −0.44 V, respectively. Finally, a mechanistic investigation illustrated that the valence electrons, charge transfer, and d-band center of the M3 active sites could collectively act as good descriptors to correlate the structure and NRR activity.
coredata.dc:title: Heterogeneous metal trimer catalysts on Mo2TiC2O2 MXene for highly active N2 conversion to NH3
